Authors:
Andy Robert Nilsen, Suliana Teasdale, Paul Leslie Guy, Tina
Claire Summerfield, David Allan Orlovich
Title:
Ectomycorrhizal fungal diversity in canopy soil of silver
beech, Lophozonia menziesii (Nothofagaceae)
Abstract:
Adventitious roots in canopy soils associated with silver
beech (Lophozonia menziesii (Hook.f.) Heenan & Smissen
(Nothofagaceae)) form ectomycorrhizal associations. We investigated the
extent to which canopy ectomycorrhizal communities contribute to overall
diversity of ectomycorrhizal fungi associated with silver beech. Hyphal
ingrowth bags were buried for 12 months in canopy and terrestrial soils
of five trees at one site. We used amplicon sequencing of the internal
transcribed spacer 2 region to assess diversity of ectomycorrhizal
fungal species. There was no significant difference in ectomycorrhizal
community diversity between the terrestrial and canopy hyphal ingrowth
bag communities, but the canopy community composition was significantly
different to the terrestrial community composition. Several abundant
ectomycorrhizal species were significantly more represented in the
terrestrial soil than the canopy soil. Non-ectomycorrhizal (termed
“residual”) fungi in the terrestrial hyphal ingrowth bags were
significantly more diverse than those in the canopy soil, and many
species were significantly more represented in either the terrestrial or
canopy communities. The canopy soil microhabitat provides a novel
environment for growth of ectomycorrhizal adventitious roots and enables
the physical partitioning of ectomycorrhizal fungal diversity in the
forest.
